availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: James P. Barbour (Washington County, Kentucky, farmer, miller, court clerk, and politician)

body.p: Washington County, Kentucky, farmer, miller, court clerk, and politician. Kentucky native. Married to Martha F. Boslee Barbour in Washington County, Kentucky, on April 27, 1835. Father of Elizabeth “Bettie” Barbour, Letitia Barbour, James Barbour, and William Barbour. Member of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Marion County from 1841 to 1842. Farmer in Marion County, Kentucky, in 1850. Owned twelve enslaved persons in Marion County in 1850. Member of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Washington County from 1850 to 1851. Delegate from Washington County to the Kentucky Democratic Party convention in Frankfort in 1858. Miller in Washington County in 1860. County court clerk in Washington County in 1860. Owned five enslaved persons in Washington County in 1860. County court clerk in Washington County in 1861. Circuit court clerk in Washington County in 1862. Circuit court clerk in Washington County in 1864. Circuit court clerk in Washington County in 1865.

Journal of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky, vol. 23, December 31, 1841 - March 3, 1842) (Frankfort: A. G. Hodges & Co., State Printers, 1841), 4.
